title: Starmer calls for Zelensky to be part of Ukraine peace talks ahead of Trump meeting
body:
With a rift opening between Europe and the White House over Ukraine, the prime minister and president Zelensky held talks on Saturday to plan for a 'very active' week ahead for the conflict
 Archie Mitchell
  Political correspondent
  Sir Keir Starmer and Volodymyr Zelensky are piling pressure on Donald Trump to ensure European leaders are at the table in talks to end Vladimir Putin 's invasion of Ukraine.
  With a rift opening between Europe and the White House over Ukraine, the prime minister and president Zelensky held talks on Saturday to plan for a "very active" week ahead for the conflict.
  French president Emmanuel Macron and Sir Keir are each visiting Mr Trump in Washington to discuss his peace plans, days after the president accused France and Britain of having "done nothing" to end the war.
  Mr Macron is expected to warn Mr Trump not to "be weak" in the face of Putin's ongoing aggression, while Sir Keir has so far been reluctant to explicitly criticise his US counterpart for fear of being dragged into a trade war.
  Speaking to Mr Zelensky on Saturday, Sir Keir repeated his calls for Ukraine to "be at the heart of any negotiations to end the war". He also said protecting Ukraine's sovereignty is essential to deterring future aggression from Russia.
  He promised to "progress these important discussions in the coming days and weeks, including with US President Trump whilst visiting Washington", a Downing Street spokesman added.
  But the PM would not commit to telling Mr Trump directly to give Ukraine a seat at the negotiating table when they meet in the White House.
  Sir Keir also spoke with European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen on Saturday, with the pair agreeing to "step up for the good of collective European security".
  The PM is expected to use his US trip to set out a much-awaited timeline for Britain to boost defence spending from 2.3 per cent to 2.5 per cent of GDP. Mr Trump has urged Nato leaders to invest more in their own defence, calling for countries to spend at least 5 per cent of their GDP on defence.
  And, in a further bid to curry favour with Mr Trump, Sir Keir is reportedly planning to give him an invite for a state visit from the King.
  But, in a move that threatens to deepen the rift between the pair on Ukraine, he is also planning a "triple whammy" of measures to pile pressure on Vladimir Putin, according to The Telegraph
  The measures are expected to include a major round of new sanctions, military aid to Ukraine and a crackdown on Russian dirty money in the UK.
  The talks coincide with the third anniversary of Putin's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, with the PM using his call with Mr Zelensky to "reiterate the UK's ironclad support for Ukraine and commitment to securing a just and enduring peace to bring an end to Russia's illegal war".
  A Downing Street spokesman added: "The leaders reflected on recent developments in the conflict, as the third anniversary of the full-scale invasion approaches, and agreed on the need to continue working together with allies to achieve peace through strength.
  "They agreed that this was a significant moment for the future of Ukraine and European security at large."
  In an interview with Fox News days after accusing Mr Zelensky of being a dictator, Mr Trump said he did not see the importance of him being involved in talks. He said Mr Zelensky has "been in the meetings for three years and nothing got done… so I don't think he's very important to be at meetings".
  Asked about the upcoming visits from Sir Keir and Mr Macron, he said: "They didn't do anything either (to end the war). The war's going on, no meetings with Russia, no nothing.
  "They haven't done anything. Macron is a friend of mine, and I've met with the Prime Minister and he's a very nice guy (but) nobody's done anything."

reasoning.presence_detection: The article explicitly references "US President Trump" and later simply "Mr Trump" in multiple contexts, confirming the target entity is present.
reasoning.statement_detection: Direct quotations attributed to Trump are present: "he did not see the importance of him being involved in talks" and "They didn't do anything either…". These are clear statements made by the entity.
reasoning.candidate_evaluation: Candidate Q22686 matches the name, description, and current position of US President. The other candidates (Trump Jr., a physician, etc.) do not align with the context or description.
reasoning.authority_verification: Q22686 holds the office of President of the United States (2025‑present) and is therefore the appropriate authority to comment on Ukraine-related matters.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for the sitting US President to make statements about Ukraine and NATO defense spending, as reflected in the article.
reasoning.final_justification: All evidence points to Q22686 as the correct Wikidata entity for the mentioned Donald Trump, both for presence and for the attributed statements.

These identifiers match the Wikidata entity’s name, title (Prime Minister of the United Kingdom), and description. No conflicting role or affiliation is presented, confirming a strong identity match.
reasoning.statement_assessment: Keir Starmer is directly quoted in the article: he repeats calls for Ukraine to be central in negotiations, states that protecting Ukraine’s sovereignty is essential, and promises to progress discussions with President Trump. These are clear statements attributed to him.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for the UK Prime Minister to make such statements about Ukraine, NATO defence spending, and diplomatic engagement with the US, given his role and the context of the article.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: No contradictions are found between the article’s depiction of Keir Starmer and the Wikidata profile. The article’s references are consistent with his position and responsibilities.

Thus, the entity (Keir Starmer) is making statements, while Ursula von der Leyen is not quoted.

input_details.description: Spokesperson for the UK Prime Minister

reasoning.identity_verification_and_presence: The article refers to a "Downing Street spokesman" who is a spokesperson for the UK Prime Minister’s office. While the office itself is not named explicitly, the spokesman’s role is to represent the Prime Minister’s Office (Q96758600). The description of the entity as "Spokesperson for the UK Prime Minister" matches the function of the Downing Street spokesman. Therefore, the entity (Prime Minister’s Office) is present in the article via its spokesperson.
reasoning.statement_assessment: The statements quoted in the article are attributed to the Downing Street spokesman, not directly to the Prime Minister’s Office. Thus, the office itself is not making statements, but it is represented by the spokesman who is making the statements.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is entirely plausible for a spokesman of the Prime Minister’s Office to make public statements on behalf of the office. The quotes in the article are consistent with a spokesperson’s role.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: No contradictions are found between the entity’s description and the article’s content. The only nuance is that the office is not named directly, but its spokesperson is mentioned, which is sufficient for identification.
